Tokenomics

Money needs a bottom. Gold's bottom isn't mining pain, it's the desire for the wedding ring and electric wire that outlives the mine. Bitcoin's solved math problems are public, worthless, unwanted. Yet Bitcoin has value. That value is cultural. The scarcity is in meaning, and math can't mint meaning; it can only ledger it.

The plum foundation owns this: we build cultural significance first, and let the tokens track the shares.

The cancer in crypto is a lack of meaning.

"Cultural Gold" is the antidote.

It's not just another project in the space; it's a philosophical rebellion against the space's hollowness.

The Economic Principles of Collectible Artifacts

The value of any collectible artifact is fundamentally determined by two factors: its scarcity and the timing of its creation relative to the cultural significance of the subject it represents. These factors combine to create a core principle:

The most desirable collectible will almost always be the agreed-upon "first," issued with sufficient float to power a liquid market and generate clear price signals, but not so abundant that it erodes scarcity.

This crucial element of timing creates two distinct classes of value: Retrospective and Prospective.

The Nature of Retrospective Value (The Common Model)

This is the most common form of a collectible. The model is straightforward:

  1. An individual, IP, or brand achieves significant cultural relevance and fame.
  2. Subsequently, a scarce "collector's edition" artifact is created to capitalize on this pre-existing demand.

A clear example is when an already famous author, like Brandon Sanderson, releases a special leather-bound edition of a beloved book. These artifacts are valuable, certainly. They are beautifully crafted and serve an existing, passionate fan base.

However, their value proposition has inherent limitations. The market understands these items were created after the risk was gone. They are commemorative, not foundational. They are a celebration of a success that has already been achieved. While they are collectible, they are not the first collectible. They are the Hall of Fame commemorative plaques, not the rookie cards. The value is established after the fact.

The Fallacy of Retroactive Value Assignment (The Digital Aberration)

The NFT boom of the last cycle attempted to apply a flawed version of the retrospective model to non-scarce digital objects. The sale of Jack Dorsey's first tweet is the canonical example.

The model was as follows:

  1. A digital object with no initial scarcity or intended value (a tweet from 2006) exists.
  2. Years later, after the platform it's on has achieved global significance, the object is tokenized.
  3. This tokenization attempts to retroactively assign scarcity and value to the original object.

This model is economically incoherent. The value assignment is arbitrary and occurs after the fact. The capital deployed by the buyer played no role in the creation of the underlying value (the success of Twitter). The title of ownership is fake. The scarcity is fake. The timing is fake. The whole thing was an attempt to purchase a memory after the fact, not an asset tied to value creation or proof of earliness.

This is also the core weakness of assets whose value is derived purely from social consensus, like a JPEG. Their cultural relevance is ephemeral. When the collective attention of the internet shifts, the asset has no underlying foundation to anchor its value. There is no tangible component, no productive utility, no reason for the desire, and no institutional mission at its core. There is no "there" there.

The Principle of Prospective Value (The Foundational Model)

This is a far rarer and more potent economic model. It inverts the entire sequence of value creation:

  1. A scarce, tangible artifact is created before the cultural significance of its underlying IP has been established. And, in this special case, when the 17-year old author, Aaliyah Corley, was a complete unknown, and before Plum Candy, her debut novel, was even published!
  2. The capital from the initial acquisition of these artifacts is used as the direct fuel to create the very cultural phenomenon that will make the artifacts valuable. In this case, we are starting by sending 100,000 USA English teachers a (non-rookie card) physical copy of Plum Candy, along with a way for them to earn a grant of 3-years of digital classroom editions for all their students if they can prove they read the book.
  3. Later tranche sales of the PLUM, also tied to the initial run of “rookie cards” will be sold to fuel additional cultural proliferation and interest in Plum Candy (like sending it to CEOs, Celebrities, and a boots on the ground campaign to hand out copies, a manhwa and a movie). The give-away copies are basic, low frills editions, not the signed rookie card edition.

This is the model upon which the PLUM asset is built.

  • The Asset: A pre-publication, serialized first edition book—the "rookie card." [Link]
  • The Timing: Created and distributed before the author is known or the novel has any cultural footprint. It is, by definition, the first collectible. It is too early, not too late.
  • The Capital Function: The acquisition of these initial assets funds a non-profit foundation. This foundation's sole mission is to execute a multi-decade strategy (classroom distribution, curriculum creation, western canon adoption, book giveaways, manhwa creation, a movie etc.) to systematically drive the IP's cultural penetration.

Unlike a retrospective collectible, a prospective artifact is not commemorative; it is foundational. The original owners are not fans celebrating a past success; they are patrons who funded a future one. The asset's value is not a static reflection of history. It is a dynamic entity, designed to accrue value from a series of deliberate, real-world initiatives with measurable KPIs. It is tethered to both a physical object and the success of an ongoing mission, providing an enduring "there" that is absent in purely retrospective or untethered digital assets.

This project is the genesis of cultural gold as the economic foundation, the bedrock, of a digital asset. This is the “bottom” that “money” needs to stop being a shell game always in search of a greater fool.

The rookie card becomes proof of earliness to a real cultural moment. Our token tracks verified cultural capital with a legitimate, desirable 'there' at the bottom.

This fundamentally redefines the holding incentive. The term “diamond hands” is no longer a call for faith-based community solidarity against market volatility, or the hopes of being on the right side of some clever market manipulation.

Instead, it becomes a descriptor for a purely rational, long-term economic strategy. Rational actors, operating in their own self-interest, are incentivized to hold the asset indefinitely. This is because the value of the artifact is a direct function of the cultural significance of the IP it represents. As the Plum Candy Foundation executes its mission, the IP's cultural footprint demonstrably grows, causing value to accrue to the foundational asset in a predictable, positive-sum game. The incentive is not to find the right moment to "pull the rug," but to remain a stakeholder in an asset whose underlying value is relentlessly increasing for obvious and predictable reasons.

Cultural Gold’s Proof of Work

Cultural Gold introduces a new paradigm for "Proof of Work."

PLUM’s proof of work is not moving stones for the sake of moving stones, like Sisyphus trying to find meaning in carrying a stone forever up a mountain. We’re not doing math for the sake of doing math.

No.

This is the opposite. This is carving and moving stones for the purpose of building a legendary castle. The money from the PLUM raises go directly into activities designed explicitly to make high school kids less dumb while expanding the cultural significance of Plum Candy.

All the "work" — every book distributed, every grant funded by the foundation — is a block laid in the castle wall, materially and demonstrably increasing the strength, permanence, ubiquity and value of the underlying culture, and by extension, the foundational artifact upon which it PLUM is built.

The PLUM token, therefore, is not a fiat currency. It is a deed. It is a fractionalized claim on the cultural real estate that you, the patron, are helping to develop. And its value will be directly proportional to the strength and grandeur of the castle.

Project Status

We have built a CRM with 100,000 USA high school English teachers.

We have built an education platform and fun, engaging lessons that align with common core objectives for Plum Candy.

We will use the funds from the initial crypto raise to fund the distribution of 100,000 physical copies of a teacher’s edition of the Plum Candy Novel to all 100,000 teachers through itscanon.com. Those books will include in them a way for these teachers to earn a grant of 3 years worth of digital classroom editions of the Plum Candy teaching curriculum.

“Worst case, you funded literacy.
Best case, you funded immortality.
Only way to lose is to watch from the sidelines.”

REGARDLESS of the quality of the book, like even if it was just barely good enough to be taught, some percentage of those teachers would choose to teach it in their class. There is a historical precedent for taking a commercially and critically failed novel, distributing 140,000 copies of it for free, and including “lesson plans” for how to teach it. That example is The Great Gatsby (read more about that here).

Now, you have no way of knowing (yet) how truly phenomenal the Plum Candy novel is. But know that we’ve made it the flagship for this new type of digital asset for a reason.

“Don’t move rocks unless it’s to build castles.”

The signed and serialized Plum Candy Rookie Card edition will be printed before anyone has heard of the book Plum Candy or the author Aaliyah Corley. Only 10,000 will ever be printed and they will be printed in a single run. Only 10,000 PLUM will ever be minted, and some will be executed immediately so that physical copies can exist in the wild and their auction prices can float independently.

Their value will track to the cultural significance of the novel over time. If it fizzles out? It’s unlikely that the collector’s edition will be worth much of anything. But if the novel becomes part of the Western canon? If it’s taught in high schools across the USA and the world? If it gets made into a blockbuster movie?

Then there’s no limit to how valuable these artifacts can become.

Consider the Michael Jordan Fleer rookie cards. They are selling for around $2 million dollars even with less than ideal economics: More than 250,000 were printed and at least 40,000 are graded.

Jordan was already known to be an amazing athlete by 1984, before the cards went to print.

Plum Candy is more speculative, but it’s this initial obscurity vs how culturally significant it becomes that will ultimately drive the resale auction prices of the physical “rookie card” books. The scarcity of only 10,000 ever existing, and created BEFORE anyone could see the success is what makes it such a fascinating collectables pick.

This could be like a 10,000 run of a 1981 Jordan High School card, if Jordan went on to invent the sport.

You’re not betting on whether Plum Candy will become more culturally significant than Michael Jordan. The point is that, by design, it doesn't have to in order for you to win.

PLUM has a convex payoff function.

If the book is merely “fine”, the tokens drift to the floor, and the rookie card will be thinly traded, if at all. You helped a few hundred thousand kids learn to write, you took a shot on a hero, and you got a beautiful book as a souvenir.

But if it becomes canon? Talked about and taught in High Schools? If it becomes a cultural touchstone? When there’s a movie? Then there is an uncapped, non-linear upside.

And who doesn’t want to be part of a winner that also helps kids? The Plum Foundation's mission is not some bullshit cover story, it’s the whole point! High schoolers ARE disinterested. They ARE worse at writing. They DON’T have a worthy hero. Executing on our mission’s roadmap is going to make meaningful improvements in how kids write, what they strive to do, and how they do it.

This can be your story too — the true story where you get to be the hero that says, “I was there at the beginning, and helped make all this happen.”

What is a PLUM?

Each PLUM will be a crypto asset bundle consisting of 1000 PLUM.X and the rights to one physical “Rookie Card” edition of the Plum Candy Novel. They can only be “detached” from each other by executing the option. Each PLUM.X can be used to access the ebook / audiobook combo. That combo (without the PLUM.X) will retail for $20. The Plum Candy Foundation, via one of the tranche raises, will fund a perpetual price floor, a standing buy order, for all 10,000,000 PLUM.X. Ideally, the executed “PLUM” should transfer on sale of the physical book like a title ownership, signal genuineness, and discourage counterfeits. (we are open to ideas and innovations on how to incentivize this).

Annual Settlement Protocol

You can be a numerologist and try to hunt for specific serial numbered copies. You can execute your call option at any time. But fulfillment of rookie card books, the shipments? That will happen just once per year.

Why?

1. It Perfectly Aligns with the "Last Man Standing" Ethos

The entire mission is about patience and conviction. An annual shipping cycle reinforces this theme at every level. It removes the impulse-driven, "I want it now" gratification that plagues so much of modern consumerism and crypto trading. By forcing a wait, the act of redemption becomes a more deliberate and thoughtful event, not traders reaction to market price.

2. It Supercharges the Scarcity Engine

It keeps the "float" of the physical artifact lighter than demand for much longer.

  • No Same-Day Arbitrage: A user redeems their PLUM, gets their PLUM.X, and their serial number is locked in. But the physical book remains in the collective "vault" for months. This prevents a flood of newly redeemed books from hitting the market simultaneously. It staggers the supply, ensuring that at any given moment, the number of physical books in the wild is far lower than the number of PLUM tokens that have been redeemed.
  • Sustained Price Pressure: This sustained scarcity of the physical asset keeps the perceived value of the unredeemed PLUM tokens higher. The market sees that even as people redeem, the actual supply of the coveted physical item remains tightly controlled. This creates a powerful, ongoing narrative of rarity.

3. It Creates a "Dual-Liquidity" Event

The redemption process now has two distinct, separate phases, each with its own market implications:

  • Phase 1: The Digital Redemption (Anytime): This is when the PLUM token is burned, and the PLUM.X is released. This is a purely on-chain event that affects the supply of the primary "cultural gold" asset (PLUM) and increases the supply of the utility token (PLUM.X).
  • Phase 2: The Physical Settlement (Annually): This is the real-world event where the physical books are finally shipped. This is the moment the supply of the tangible, collectible asset actually increases.

Separating these two events creates a fascinating dynamic. The market can price in the impending physical supply for months before it actually materializes, leading to complex speculation and strategic trading around the annual shipping date.

4. It Drastically Lowers Overhead and Complexity

The logistical benefit is massive. Consolidating 500 or 1000 potential individual shipments into one annual run is efficient and cost-effective. This reduces the operational drag on the foundation, ensuring more of the Curation Fees and other revenues go directly into the mission (the "Cultural Endowment") rather than being eaten by shipping costs.

Conclusion: It Solidifies the "LTBH Only" Crowd

This protocol is ultimately a filter. It effectively weeds out anyone looking for a quick arbitrage flip. The friction — the waiting period — is a feature, not a bug. It ensures that only those with genuine long-term conviction will participate. It's a self-selecting mechanism that builds a community of true believers and patrons, rather than speculative traders.

The digital asset (PLUM) is liquid and tradable 24/7, but the ultimate prize (the physical book) is governed by the patience of a cathedral builder. This contrast between the frantic digital market and the deliberate, physical world is a powerful narrative in itself.

The Public Auction & Price Discovery Engine

Holders of PLUM are encouraged to bid on physical rookie card books in the wild that are in auction. First, because they want the book. But also because it is part of the function that drives the value of PLUM.

The books that sell for $5k, $25k, or $50k at Sotheby's become headlines in and of themselves, driving more people to ask “why?” and “How can I get in on this?”

1. "How can I get the rookie card of rookie cards?" — The Meta-Narrative Hook

This is the appeal to the visionary and the historian. This isn't about a book; it's about being there at the dawn of a new asset class.

  • Target Audience: The tech futurist, the venture capitalist, the sophisticated art collector who understands paradigm shifts. The person who bought early Bitcoin not just to get rich, but because they believed in the technology.
  • The Psychological Trigger: FOMO on History. This isn't just fear of missing out on a financial gain; it's fear of missing out on being a founding member of a new movement. Owning a PLUM token is positioned as owning a share in the "Apple 1" or the "Mona Lisa" of cultural gold. It's a status symbol that signals you're not just rich, but prescient.
  • The Conversion: This person doesn't just buy a token; they buy into the story of `prenormous.com`. They are investing in the blueprint itself, making the "rookie card of rookie cards" the most compelling asset allocation in their portfolio.

2. "Shouldn't that be in my portfolio?" — The Financial Rationalization Hook

This is the appeal to the pragmatist and the institutional investor. It reframes the entire project from a speculative cultural bet into a legitimate, alternative asset class.

  • Target Audience: Family offices, hedge funds, high-net-worth individuals, and serious collectors who think in terms of portfolio diversification and risk-adjusted returns.
  • The Psychological Trigger: Validation and Prudence. The $50k auction price is a third-party, market-driven validation that is impossible to fake. It answers the question, "Is this real?" with a resounding "Yes." It transforms the purchase from an emotional gamble into a rational financial decision. The thinking becomes, "A market for this exists, it's proven, and as an early asset, it has convex upside. It would be irresponsible not to have a small allocation."
  • The Conversion: This person buys PLUM after running the numbers. They are attracted to the scarcity, the self-sustaining financial model (Curation Fees), and the clear path to value accrual. They see it as a hedge against inflation and a bet on the tokenization of real-world assets.

3. "How good is this damn book that people are paying $50k for it!?!?" — The Cultural Curiosity Hook

This is the appeal to the everyman and the art lover. It bypasses all the complex financial mechanics and goes straight to the heart of the matter: the art itself.

  • Target Audience: The general public, book lovers, students, teachers, and anyone susceptible to a great story. This is your widest net.
  • The Psychological Trigger: Pure Intrigue. The price creates an aura of legendary status around the novel. It's the modern-day equivalent of hearing about a "cursed painting" or a "lost manuscript." The question isn't "What's the ROI?" but "What's the story?" It creates a powerful desire to engage with the source material, to understand what could possibly inspire such passion and value.
  • The Conversion: This person doesn't buy a token first. They buy the book. They visit bitterenders.com. They talk to their friends about it. They become part of the cultural groundswell that gives the PLUM asset its fundamental value. They are the "proof of work" in action, and their engagement is what ultimately justifies the $50k price tag to the other two groups.

The Synergy of the Three Hooks

The three hooks feed each other in a virtuous cycle:

  • The Cultural Curiosity (3) creates the organic, grassroots buzz that makes the project feel real and meaningful.
  • This grassroots buzz provides the social proof that allows the Financial Rationalization (2) to take hold. Institutions see a real cultural movement, not just a white paper.
  • The combination of a real cultural movement and financial validation creates the legendary status needed for the Meta-Narrative (1) to become the "rookie card of rookie cards."

The auction headline is yet another catalyst that ignites all three at once. They are events that speak a different language to each member of your target audience, inviting them all into the same ecosystem from different directions. It's a vortex, not a funnel.

As Plum Candy gets more cultural penetration, more kids read it and the study guides, they learn the author is “one of them” and that they can do it too, or something similarly ambitious, if they work hard enough.

The money, the value, the clout—it's all instrumental. The ultimate goal is for a kid in a high school English class, 20 years from now, to read Plum Candy from a tattered classroom set. They'll finish the last page, their mind blown, and their teacher will tell them the story behind the book: the story of a 17 year old girl author who worked on and believed in their art so much they built a new system to give it to the world, proving that a great story could have a value beyond money.

That’s Cultural Endowment: that’s the real return on investment.

The Last Man Standing Protocol

(Fort Knox for a Cultural Reserve)

Most projects beg you to claim early.

We dare you to claim last.

The smart contract is a single descending integer, visible to every eye, editable by none.

10 000… 9 999… 9 998…

Each burn of a PLUM peels off the next serial—highest first, lowest last—until the final patron, years or decades from now, is handed Book #1.

No lottery, no auction, no favouritism.

The grail is not bought; it is out-waited.

The protocol creates a massive, sustained economic incentive NOT to redeem.

Patience is the only hash-rate this chain recognises.

Every extra season you hold tightens the screw on everyone else: the float of sealed tokens shrinks, the counter keeps ticking, and your unmoved PLUM retains its option on a lower—and therefore slightly scarcer—number.

In the end, the last unmoved token simply inherits the smallest digit; no multiplier is promised, only the quiet prestige of having endured longest.

Secondary games will orbit the descent.

A numerologist will stalk #1984, a patriot #1776, a whale may try to corner the final hundred—discovering that the market price of patience rises exponentially as the counter nears zero.

These are side quests, not bugs.

The protocol does not care why you burn, only that the digit is gone for good.

Schrödinger’s Rookie Card

The sealed token is the living asset: pure, unspent potential—Schrödinger’s rookie card, still #8000, still #42, still #1—until the moment you tear it open. Everyone who still owns PLUM has a shared stake in #1.

Trade the probability, not the paper.

While it stays sealed the market can price the chance that it lands inside the sub-100 set, or on any other culturally resonant integer.

The mechanism was engineered to keep the dream in motion and the books locked inside a forever vault: Fort Knox for a cultural reserve.

Immortality has a modest upkeep.

Once a year the vault demands a petty tithe—ten dollars, maybe twenty—paid in stable coin to the same contract that holds the counter.

Miss the fee and the seal breaks: the token is auto-burned, the PLUM.X appears in your wallet, the book ships to your last on-file address.

You lose nothing but your seat in the waiting game.

Over decades the forgotten wallets—lost keys, dead founders, estate lawyers who never read the white paper—will quietly graduate, ensuring the countdown can never be frozen by ghosts. Each defection shortens the queue for the stubborn remainder and sweeps another micro-donation into the Cultural Endowment that pays for translations, teacher grants, and the next plain-text printing.

The patron who finally receives Book #1 will have paid storage fees for half a lifetime; their serial number is therefore a receipt for decades of patronage, not a lottery ticket.

This is a game designed to outlast its players—to far outlast a 17-year-old author and her initial patrons. The protocol is built for endurance, not for an ending. The counter may never reach 00001.

But should that day ever come, the chain will imprint that final address forever. No one will need to explain why the book is valuable; the timestamp will be a part of the legend.

Until then, the counter keeps falling—and the rest of us discover how long we can resist opening the pack.

Rolling Capital
